sub_title: Researcher 3D Printed Electronics for TNO at Holst Centre
summary:
Chemical engineer with an interest for molecular systems with functional applications to make the world a more sustainable and enjoyable place.

As a PhD candidate and researcher at Eindhoven University of Technology, I focused on the development of autonomously responsive materials for functional devices based on liquid crystalline polymers. The combination of novel materials of that type with additive manufacturing was used to create “4D printed” devices, such as a beetle that changes colour when in contact with water, or a clamshell design that opens and shuts in response to atmospheric humidity. This research was made possible by a complete chain-of-knowledge approach from the organic synthesis used to make the functional monomers, to processing into the devices, and finally thorough characterisation and dissemination in the form of academic journal articles and at public events.

After graduating with the thesis “Cholesteric Liquid Crystals in Additive Manufacturing”, I worked briefly for deep-tech university spin-off Lusoco on the development of luminescent inks for solar energy harvesting materials. Since October of 2022, I'm employed by TNO at Holst Centre, where my expertise in polymer and materials science is used in the research of 3D printed electronics.

awards: [{'title': 'Winner ‘KNCV Challa Polymer Award 2023’', 'description': 'The Challa Polymer Award is a biennial prize awarded by the KNCV Section Macromolecules for the best PhD thesis in the field of polymer chemistry and polymer technology from a Dutch university, in this case over the years 2021 and 2022. \nThe jury consisted of a select group of independent academics in these research field, and the prize is named after prof. em.
